title: Style in the Long Tail: Discovering Unique Interests with Latent Variable Models in Large Scale Social E-commerce
segmentation: So my name is Diane, who I'm from the data science team at C and I'm going to be sharing about some of the work that we've done in building recommender systems for our very unique marketplace.
This is joint work with Rob Hall and Josh Ahnberg, both of 'em from Etsy as well.
So I'm going to start off by giving an overview for those of you who are not familiar with the site.
So at C is an online marketplace.
Where people from all over the world can connect to buy and sell unique goods, and these goods are unique in the sense that most of them are one of a kind, or they're sold in very small quantities.

So in order for an item to be sold on, Etsy has to either fall into one of these three categories, it must either be handmade by an individual or a group of individuals, or it must be vintage, which is 20 years or older, or it must be a craft supply, just some sort of raw material that's used to create other items that can be sold on Etsy.
So this is just an example of what an empty storefront looks like.
This is one of my favorite sellers, Yvonne, who makes these beautiful leather handmade backpacks.
And she's from Spain.
So.

So just to give you an idea of our user base, we have 40 million registered users, have a total of 1 million shops, and at any given time we have about 26 million active listings and we're also not just limited to the US.
We have the site is translated in nine different languages and we have buyers and sellers that live in over 200 different countries.
So clearly Etsy is a very unique marketplace.
Each of our 1,000,000 sellers brings his or own very particular quirks and personality, and it's well known that people come to Etsy specifically to find unusual items that match their personalities.
In this talk, I want to highlight how else is kind of different from your typical ecommerce site and as a result how we approach recommender systems in order to tailor.
To such a unique place.
So one of the main ways that see differs from a typical ecommerce site is the way in which users interact with our site.
The dotted line here is meant to illustrate how users usually interact with the ecommerce site so.
By the time they go to any Commerce site, they usually have a very good idea of what they want to buy, so their path through the site is very intentional.
They might go and search for something you know.
Look at some models, compare some items, and then at the end of that their main action is basically to decide whether or not to purchase an item.
While this is true for a lot of Xe visitors as well, we also have a good portion of people who come to Etsy simply just to browse and with not a lot of, or at least a very vague.
Purchase intent and so we have a lot of content to make this browsing experience as enjoyable as possible.
For example, our front page.
We have these things called browse slices and a user's activity feed.
So another thing is that our users love to curate items that catches their eye so they can do this by favoriting items or shops, and they can also add these to smaller collections and organize them.
Most of the time the collections are with some sort of very coherent visual style and this is.
This is usually done with very little intent of purchasing, and it's a process that they really enjoy.
Um?

An additional action that they can do is they can follow users with similar style or taste and this just shows them the activity of other users and this is a great way for people to discover other relevant items that are similar to their styles or interests.
So shopping on Etsy can also be a very different experience, so this is what you get when you search for something like night stand.
You get over 100 pages of extremely diverse and eclectic styles, even though all of these results are categorically relevant, they're all you know.
All night stands probably only a very small subset will appeal to your personal style.
So.
An interesting phenomenon that we see at sea is that our users will actually page through many many pages of search results in order to find what they're looking for.

So we've done user studies and we found that a lot of our users exhibit this feeling of fear of missing out, where similar to your thrifting at the thrift shop, you know that that perfect unique item is out there, and if you just search long and hard enough, you're going to find it and.
All of the burden kind of is on the user to find this perfect thing that they're looking for.

So one of our goals and building recommender systems is to be able to minimize the amount of shifting that the user has to do and not only surfaced items that are functionally relevant, but also relevant to the user's style as well.
So we've talked a lot about this idea of style and that it's really important to our users, but unfortunately it can be really difficult to describe with words.

So for example, here are two two people's list of favorite items, and even though you might not have adequate vocabulary to describe exactly what each of these individual styles are, you can see from the images that there are different.
Um?
So the good news is that people usually know what they like when they see it, and so one can argue that it's easier to describe style with images instead of words.
So another one of our goals is to be able to surface these styles in a way that's visually transparent, understandable.
So just to sum up, the last couple of slides we've seen a couple of ways in which FC is unique and as a result, the personalization on SC will look a little different as well.
So first we want to be able to provide recommendations for.

Multiple intents for enhancing the browsing experience, and so we're not here just to optimize, you know, purchase predictions we really want to be able to seamlessly integrate with the way that users currently use the site.

2nd, we have a variety of content on Etsy, so we're not just going to be recommending items we want to be able to have a unified method that recommends shops and items and users all with the same notions of similar styles and interests that we talked about earlier.
And then finally, I'm probably most importantly SC is a very visual experience and a lot of users identify what they like their images and so.
And also I should mention that our sellers invest a lot of time in photographing their products in a way that convey their personal style and their brand.
And so we not only want to identify user styles and interests, but we want to do so in a way that's visual.
Alright, so in this next section I'm going to talk about exactly how we go about finding this different.
These different styles on Etsy and how we used.
So this is an overview of where we're headed.
Our goal is first to learn these things called style profiles for each user and what this should do is summarize this strength of interest in each of these styles for user.
So this is what my style profile might look like.
The second thing would be to be able to define each of these styles.
Ideally with images so that they're easy to understand, and then third, we're going to use these style profiles to generate all these different personalized recommendations on Etsy.
So to accomplish.
This method is very straightforward.
We use a popular topic modeling algorithm called the inversely allocation.
So LDA for short.
So as most of you probably already know, LDA is a generative model that specifies a probabilistic process by which your observed data is generated by.

So for us we decided to model our users favourites data because this most accurately described their taste preferences or their style preferences and it also has the added advantage that it's not as sparse as our purchase data.

So our reason for using LDA comes from the idea that styles on Etsy is very similar to topics in text, which is what LDA is traditionally used to model in text when you have words that Co occur frequently in a document.
In many documents, this usually means that there they belong to some sort of higher level semantic topic in the same way for styles.
If you have items that are frequently favorited together by users, this might.
Indicate that there's some sort of underlying style that they all have in common.
So in our model, each user is represented as a document.
So as you can see from the figure.
The page icon represents a document and each of the words in the document is basically just the listing ID of the favorited item of the user.
So, just to clarify, we don't use any content from the actual listings or the items, it's literally just a list of the numerical unique listing IDs.
So we assume this generative process that will generate each of the users favorite items.
And before I go go through the process, we assume that, for example, we have all of the OR.
We know the values of the parameters and.
The most important thing here is that beta matrix, which is what?
Defines each of our styles and.
This is basically each style is defined as a distribution over all the items on Etsy.
So assuming that we already know what that is, the process for which we generate each user's favorite items.
Is.
So for each user we first draw style profile for that user and this is represented by this data vector, which is basically a distribution over the case tiles that it's learned.
And then for each favorite item that the user has, we draw.
A style from the style profile.

So in this example, for example, one of the styles is called surreal, which will see some images for later, and then once you have that style for that item, you draw the actual item from the styles distribution, which is specified by that data.
Parameter.
And then you continue doing this and drawing items until you've drawn every single item that user has favorited.

So this is the process by which we assume that favorite items are created for users and then to use this model, we basically estimate the parameters and infer the random variables and we give sampling.
This is a very standard method.
There's a lot of literature on it, so I won't go into detail on that.
But the takeaway here is that we learn very two very important representations, so the first is the is the style item matrix, so this is how we define our styles.
It's a distribution over the K. Or.
Sorry, it's K styles distributed over the total listings on Etsy, and what I've shown here is just the top weighted items in each style and these should indicate that there.
Most visually representative of that style, and then I've manually labeled each of these topics as whatever it seems like the images have in common.
So the first topic is, for example, geometric contains a lot of items have kind of a geometric aesthetic.

On the second representation, is that style profile that's learned for each user, so this basically tells you or this is a distribution over the styles over the case styles that it's learned, and it basically tells you how strong of an interest the user has in each of these styles.
So one of the cool parts is that LDA actually model our data very well.
So here's a closer look at some of the styles or topics that I discovered.
These are some of my favorite ones that I pulled in all of these.
I want to contrast all of these different styles that were art prints were highly weighted.
And so for example, or each column contains the most highly weighted items for that style.
So for example, the first style contains a lot of like whimsical botanical art prints.
The second style has a lot of items that are of this kind of eerie, surreal nature.
Third style has these whimsical animal prints.
And so on.
OK, and then these are a couple of different more styles that just kind of illustrate the types of things that it discovered.
Some of EM have like a common theme like animals and tentacles.
They're not really aesthetic themes.
While like the geometric theme, is quite aesthetic.
And then we've got like the art prints.
We've got styles that are all within the same category like mid century Modern furniture.
OK.

This is very straightforward once we have user or style profiles for each user we want to recommend the top end users with the most similar style profiles and I'm running out of time, so I'm going to gloss over this, but we use a pretty standard hashing methods that we implement on map reduce in order to accommodate our enormous user base.
For item recommendations, we basically sample.

Items from each user is most highly weighted styles, so for example, the top row is the users favourites and then the bottom two rows shows the top four styles that the user had most highly weighted and.
Some some items that are sampled from those styles and so these would be the items that we would recommend.
For shop recommendations, it's very similar to how we do item recommendations, except that we re learn the topic models and we substitute the item IDs with the shop IDs.
That item is from and so we end up with is.
A style shop matrix where all of the styles are defined as distribution over shops.
So these are just some.
Examples of.
What are recommendations look like so on the left side are actually my own favorite from Etsy with the Orange border and then on the right is my coauthor.
Josh is an.
You can see that we kind of have similar styles like kind of like bright modern things, but Josh has a much stronger.
He really likes furniture and so most of his shop recommendations are very furniture heavy, whereas mine are more diverse across a bunch of categories.

With my other Co author Rob Hall who he just likes guns and knives and masks, and so the shop recommendations that he gets reflects that.

We can also do or.
Sorry not visualizations, but recommendations is now.
We can also recommend items from specific categories, so going back to that night stand example in the beginning.

A little kind of like vintage mid century modern.
So.

Other cool thing we did was we computed the covariance matrix with the aggregate of the user style profiles and so we can see which styles are highly correlated with each other and what we got were these cool clusters of related topics or styles and so some of them were more like just very similar aesthetic like this one just shows a bunch of topics that are kind of bright and whimsical.
Some are, some actually show styles that are complementary to each other, so I manually labeled this Gothic punk.
I don't know if that's correct, but it kind of shows what one might be interested in in terms of jewelry, apparel and decor or art.
If you're into Gothic punk.
And then finally, some of these are just a lot of the topics have a similar theme, so this is like a sci-fi fantasy theme.
You've got your Harry Potter or Batman, The Avengers and Doctor Who.
OK, so going back to recommendations and talking a little bit about how we evaluated them.
The first product that we chose to kind of test our recommendations and was our activity feed which depending on what experiment your bucket in, this might be our home page.
When you go in and see right now.
So the activity feed was originally just a continuous stream of activity from the people that you follow.
And now with these additional shop and item and User X story cards, we've created a much more diverse and yet targeted browsing experience for our users.
And so we were able to do some pretty extensive testing and evaluating our recommendations.
The first thing that we did was just a really simple side-by-side user study as a sanity check.

We randomly interleaved user recommendations from three different models, neither pretty simple baseline models, LDA being one of them, and we ask users to rate each recommendation positive, neutral and negative, and in this method, LDA was the overwhelming winner.

And then from there we moved to actually deploy this into our onto the Live FC website during the first phase we just tested these new LDA based recommendations versus no recommendations, and thankfully it showed that personalization was a huge win and increased business metrics all across the board.

And in the second phase we implemented a couple of different variations on the LDA algorithm and also some more traditional collaborative filtering methods, and I think the takeaway there was that the matrix factorization LDA, were comparable.
Alright, so to summarize what we've done so far, we identified a bunch of styles across SC as a visually transparent experience.
We generated style profiles that were able to capture diverse taste.

We built several large scale recommender systems for multiple content types and for enhancing our users browse experience and we were able to improve key business metrics all across the board with our recommendation systems.
And so obviously I had a gloss over a lot of details.
You're interested, please read our paper.
Thank you very much.
